I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will strengthen Pakistan’s food 
security and resilience in agriculture. The TA is a response to the impacts of the coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19) pandemic and an unprecedented locust infestation. The TA will support the 
Ministry  of  National  Food  Security  and  Research  (MNFSR)  and  four  provincial  agriculture 
departments1 in (i) adopting technologies and advanced practices to manage the impacts of 
COVID-19, locust swarms, and climate change impacts on agriculture productivity and the value 
chain; (ii) disseminating these technologies and practices to beneficiaries, including government 
and rural communities; and (iii) assessing agriculture and food security institutions and sector 
performance to recommend measures for building long-term resilience and sustainable food 
security systems.  
 
2.  The TA is not included in the current country operations business plan.2 The TA is aligned 
with Pakistan’s country partnership strategies for 2015–2019 and 2020–2024.3 The TA meets 
Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 1, 2, 5, and 13,4 and Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
Strategy 2030 operational priorities (OPs) 1, 2, 3, 5, and 6.5 
  
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.     Food insecurity and rural poverty. Pakistan is facing high levels of food insecurity. More 
than 20% of its population is undernourished, 24% is living below the national poverty line, and 
about 39% is categorized as multidimensional poor.6 Agriculture contributes to more than 19% of 
gross domestic product, employs 39% of the labor force, and directly and indirectly delivers nearly 
80% of the total value of exports.7 Yet, the average growth rate of agriculture from 2010–2011 to 
2019–2020 decreased compared with the 2000s. Agriculture is not performing to its potential.8 
The current food security portfolio and future direction need to be rigorously analyzed to see if 
they support the long-term strategic priority of improving resilience in food security and agriculture.  
 
4.  Compounded challenges of pandemic and unprecedented pest attack. COVID-19 
has spread rapidly, with 338,000 cases and 6,867 deaths as of 4 November 2020.9 The country 
is vulnerable to food insecurity, with 37% of the population (212 million) vulnerable to hunger. 
Confinement measures imposed by the Government of Pakistan in response to COVID-19 have 
disrupted the food supply chain. Overlying these impacts is the largest locust infestation in 25

years. Locust swarms migrating from neighboring Iran have devastated large areas of agricultural 
land, ravaging cotton, wheat, maize, and other crops.10 A preliminary high-level estimate for the 
worst case scenario predicts that about 34,000 households (238,000 people) in Balochistan, 
Punjab, and Sindh will be impacted by food insecurity. In response, Pakistan declared an 
emerg‐ency in February 2020 and commenced a national surveillance and control operation.  
 
5.  Inefficient food system and price inflation. COVID-19 impacts and the locust outbreak 
slowed the economy. Growth for 2019–2020 was projected at 3.2% but subsequently reassessed 
at –0.4%.11 Crop damage prompted Pakistan to miss its production target for wheat by about 2 
million tons, leading the country to import wheat for the first time since 2014. Low yields resulted 
in wheat and other food grain price increases, pushing general inflation in September 2020 to  
9.0%  nationwide  and  11.1%  in  rural  areas.12 Loss  of  incomes  and  remittances  reduced 
purchasing power and induced food security risks.13 More than 35% of the country’s rural 
population lives below the national poverty line. Households reliant on farming, and particularly 
women, are highly vulnerable to economic shocks due to disruptions in access to income, 
education, and health care, and gender pay gaps. 
 
6.  Weak institutional capacity and coordination challenges. Agriculture is a provincial 
subject, while food security and export policy and regulations lie within the federal domain of the 
MNFSR.14 Any initiative to strengthen food security and agriculture requires a coordinated and 
informed effort between provincial and federal governments. Commodities and food information 
from existing systems (e.g., crop reporting services, provincial bureaus of statistics) are neither 
comprehensive nor up to the standard required to support timely policy decision-making. Limited 
institutional capacity to process and analyze data poses further constraints, contributing to 
country-wide challenges in procuring, distributing, and pricing commodities (e.g., wheat). 
  
7.  Outdated systems and technologies. Pakistan relies on outdated pest management, 
including obsolete knowledge and practices to combat locusts and other pests. These require 
upgrading to meet international standards for pest, especially locust, management. Bio-friendly 
options  need  to  be  adopted  to  increase  safety  and  sustain  ecosystems.  Information  and 
communication  technology  (ICT)  and  remote-sensing  technologies  are  not  used  for  data 
collection and associated food-monitoring systems. Manual data gathering delays decision-
making on food pricing, commodity movement, among others, and negatively impacts food 
security. 
  
8.  Risk of climate change impacts. Pakistan is fifth on the list of countries that have 
remained most affected by climate change since the 2000s.15 It is one of the most vulnerable to 
climate change, with recurrent catastrophes of extreme weather events, including floods, droughts, 
and heat waves. The country’s food security and agriculture are critically exposed to the adverse 
impacts of climate change. The adoption of climate-adaptive crop protection and production 
practices will improve resilience in agriculture.

9.  Lack of gender inclusion. About 79% of rural women are engaged in agriculture.16 They 
perform fundamental roles in livestock, crop harvest, and post-harvest support. Their contributions 
are largely overlooked in agriculture planning and investments.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: national food security sustained; resilience 
in agriculture and national food security increased; and national targets for agricultural growth 
achieved.17 The TA will have the following outcome: institutional capacity to manage a sustainable 
food security system strengthened.18  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output 1: Technology-based data collection practices demonstrated. The project will 
support the MNFSR and the four provincial agriculture departments in designing, planning, and 
implementing agriculture data collection using the latest technology. The project will provide more 
reliable and timely data on agriculture production, commodity prices, and the supply chain. The 
project will (i) conduct surveys across four provinces to collect sample data on COVID-19 and the 
impact of locust infestation on farming households and commodity price fluctuations,19 (ii) design 
and demonstrate ICT-based crop reporting practices for village data collection, and (iii) prepare a 
model for remote-sensing crop assessment and perform enumerated data validation. The project 
will help improve historical data for effective policy making.  
 
12.  Output 2: Advanced locust and other pest management practices disseminated. The 
project will support the MNFSR through the Department of Plant Protection (DPP) and provincial 
agriculture  departments  in (i)  demonstrating  at  least  three  of  the  latest technologies (e.g., 
biopesticides,  ICT-supported  drones)  applying  international  best  practices  in  safe  and 
environment-friendly management of locusts and other pests;20 and (ii) training at least 200 
officials  from  DPP  and  four  provincial  agriculture  departments  to  apply  integrated  pest 
management practices, and training master trainers.21  
 
13.  Output 3: Climate-adaptive and disaster-resilient agriculture practices increased in 
areas vulnerable to climate change and natural  hazards. The project will support rural 
communities increase their capacity to combat the impacts of climate change and natural hazards. 
The project will (i) provide at least 2,000 farmers and staff members of local nongovernment 
organizations  (NGOs),  10%  of  whom  are  women,  with  best  practices  in  sustainable  crop 
protection; and (ii) demonstrate at least three technologies for climate-adaptive seed development 
or  crop  production.  Activity  (i)  will  conduct  master  training  on  adopting  ecosystem-friendly 
practices. It will upgrade women’s skills in climate-adaptive and disaster-resilient crop seed

cleaning and storage, leading to increased crop productivity and higher incomes.  
 
14.  Output 4: Diagnostic assessment of food security and agriculture completed. The 
project will support the MNFSR in conducting a diagnostic assessment of food security and 
agriculture. The project will contribute to timely and evidence-based policy decisions on key 
priorities  such  as  essential  commodity  production  and  forecasting,  real-time  monitoring  of 
availability and pricing of commodities, and financial inclusion opportunities for small farmers. The 
project will (i) consult diverse groups of stakeholders, including the government (federal and 
provincial), farmers, NGOs, the private sector, and international development partners; and (ii) 
prepare a diagnostic assessment report.22  
 
15.  Innovation and ADB’s value addition. The TA will promote innovative solutions to 
effectively respond to COVID-19 and locust outbreaks and to the challenges of building long-term 
sustainable  food  security.  The  TA  will  bring  best  international  practices  using  advanced 
technologies and knowledge into the food security system and agriculture through demonstration, 
collaborating with reputable international knowledge institutes (footnote 20). The TA will offer 
integrated solutions to resolve a range of issues with a “One ADB” approach that applies cross-
cutting knowledge and innovations.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,500,000, of which (i) $600,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6); (ii) $500,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by TASF-others from the COVID-19 Corporate Pool; (iii) $200,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by the Climate Change Fund;23 and (iv) $200,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Netherlands Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership Facility and administered 
by ADB.24 The key expenditure items are in Appendix 2. The government will provide counterpart 
support in the form of counterpart staff, data and information access, secretarial assistance, 
coordination, domestic transportation for counterpart staff, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB  will  administer  the  TA.  The MNFSR,  through  the Office  of  the Food  Security 
Commissioner,  will  be  the  executing  agency.  The  provincial  agriculture  departments  of 
Balochistan,  Khyber  Pakhtunkhwa,  Punjab,  and  Sindh,  through  their  offices  of  extension 
directorates, will be the implementing agencies.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the 
equivalent of $200,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Netherlands Trust Fund under the 
Water Financing Partnership Facility, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the 
equivalent of $1,300,000 on a grant basis to the Government of Pakistan for Strengthening Food 
Security Post–COVID-19 and Locust Attacks, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1. Technology-based data collection practices demonstrated 
1.1 Mobilize consultants by mid-December 2020. 
1.2 Review the present system, ongoing and planned initiatives, and the need assessment for 
strengthening ICT-based crop reporting data collection by February 2021. 
1.3 Design and conduct sample surveys of farm households, including gender-specific data and 
mechanized agriculture service providers, using CAPI in collaboration with the MNFSR by June 
2021. 
1.4 Analyze impacts of COVID-19 and locust attacks on farm households and the value chain and 
share the results with the MNFSR and all four provincial agriculture departments for their policy 
decisions by September 2021.  
1.5 Develop and demonstrate the architecture of ICT-based CRS applying village data collection, and 
conduct master training for master trainers for CRS staff members of all four provincial agriculture 
departments by August 2021. 
1.6 Demonstrate ICT-based CRS in all four provinces, and collect and process data uploaded on the 
provincial agriculture departments’ CRS website within 30 days after the data collection date by 
December 2021.

geographic areas using the latest spatial (open source) data and demonstrate assessment 
practices by August 2021

December 2021.
